questions.text:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, and occasional constipation is scheduled for an 11 a.m. colonoscopy in several weeks. His medication list includes aspirin, lisinopril, pantoprazole, and pravastatin.
His last colonoscopy, conducted at age 65, revealed two tubular adenomas, measuring < 1 cm each, in the ascending and sigmoid colon. The bowel preparation for that procedure involved 4 liters of polyethylene glycol taken the night before; however, the quality of the preparation was described as poor.
Which one of the following bowel preparations is recommended for this patient for his upcoming procedure?

choices.text: Stool softener twice daily now and 4 liters of polyethylene glycol the night before the procedure
Sodium phosphate preparation the day before the procedure
Increased fiber intake to 20 g per day now, followed by 4 liters of polyethylene glycol the night before the procedure
Two liters of polyethylene glycol the evening before the procedure and 2 liters of polyethylene glycol the morning of the procedure
Clear liquids for 72 hours before the procedure, followed by 2 liters of polyethylene glycol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Data do not support chronic use of stool softeners, although oral or rectal stimulant laxatives can be recommended at the start of the preparation.

Patients should reduce fiber intake or supplementation one week before the procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

Sodium phosphate bowel preparations are no longer recommended, particularly in older patients, because of the risks of potentially fatal fluid and electrolyte shifts and acute phosphate nephropathy. These problems especially affect patients with kidney disease or reduced intravascular volume and those taking angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers, or nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients should reduce fiber intake or supplementation one week before the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

Poor bowel preparations affect up to 22% of colonoscopies, limiting the identification of polyps < 5 mm in size. A split-dose preparation of polyethylene glycol solution, which involves half the volume of preparation being given the night before the procedure and half being given the morning of, is superior to exclusive evening-before dosing. In some studies, split dosing increased the number of excellent or adequate preparations by 30% to 40%. The morning dose must be completed at least 4 hours before receipt of anesthesia.

Key learning point: The most effective approach to improving the quality of a colonic preparation is to split the preparation, with half given the night before the procedure and half given the morning of the procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

A clear liquid diet can improve the quality of bowel preparation, but it is rarely recommended for longer than 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with a history of hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, and chronic kidney disease related to diabetic nephropathy presents to the emergency department with painless hematochezia. He describes two episodes of bright-red blood filling the toilet bowl, without any preceding abdominal pain or cramping. He has not had hypotension or sick contacts. His last colonoscopy 3 years ago showed diverticulosis and an 8-mm adenomatous polyp in the transverse colon; the polyp was completely removed. His current medications are rosuvastatin, semaglutide, aspirin, and amlodipine.
He has a blood pressure of 131/69 mm Hg, a heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and a temperature of 37.3°C. Physical examination is remarkable only for mild diffuse discomfort on palpation of the abdomen.
His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL (baseline, 13.5; reference range, 13.5–17.5), and his serum creatinine level is 2.2 mg/dL (baseline, 2.0; reference range, 0.8–1.3). His international normalized ratio is 1.0.
He is evaluated by gastroenterology and scheduled for colonoscopy the next morning.
What is the most appropriate bowel preparation for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy recommends avoiding magnesium citrate-based preparation in patients older than age 65, those with renal disease, and those taking medications that alter renal blood flow or electrolyte excretion. This patient is older than age 65 and has known chronic kidney disease; therefore, a magnesium citrate-based preparation would not be appropriate for him.

B) INCORRECT:

A clear liquid diet alone is not sufficient bowel preparation for colonoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sodium phosphate-based preparations should be avoided because of the risk of electrolyte abnormalities and renal complications, even in healthy patients. Similarly, bisacodyl should be avoided because of the risk of ischemic colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Sodium phosphate-based preparations should be avoided because of the risk of electrolyte abnormalities and renal complications, even in healthy patients. Similarly, bisacodyl should be avoided because of the risk of ischemic colitis.

E) CORRECT:

The choice of bowel preparation for colonoscopy depends on patient-specific risk factors, as well as patient preferences about the volume of the preparation, prior experience with the preparation, and cost.

Electrolyte lavage solutions containing polyethylene glycol (PEG) are generally safe for all patients. These solutions are the preferred preparation for patients >65 years of age, given their increased risk for fluid and electrolyte abnormalities, and for patients with heart failure, renal insufficiency, end-stage liver disease, inflammatory bowel disease, and electrolyte imbalances — including patients who take diuretics. Split dosing (in which half of the preparation is taken the night before colonoscopy and half is taken the morning of) is recommended.

Key learning point: The most appropriate bowel preparation for a patient older than age 65 with a history of chronic kidney disease is an electrolyte lavage solution containing polyethylene glycol.
